    Spatial Trajectory Analysis

    spata-v2-trajectory-analysis.Rmd

    1. Introduction

    With spatial trajectory analysis SPATA2 introduces a new approach to find, analyze and visualize differently expressed genes and gene-sets in a spatial context. While the classic differential gene expression analyzes differences between experimental groups as a whole it neglects changes of expression levels that can only be seen while maintaining the spatial dimensions. Spatial trajectories allow to answer questions that include such a spatial component. E.g.:

    1. In how far do expression levels change the more we move towards a region of interest?
    2. Which genes follow the same pattern along these paths?

    The spatial trajectory tools provided in SPATA2 enable new ways of visualization as well as new possibilities to screen for genes, gene-sets and patterns of interest.

    # load packages
library(SPATA2)

# load spata-object 
spata_obj <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-gbm275.RDS")

    2. Draw trajectories

    Spatial trajectories of a sample in a given spata-object can be drawn interactively using the function createTrajectories()as shown in the example below. createTrajectories() opens a mini-shiny application. This app allows one the one hand to investigate the sample with regards to spatial gene expression like plotSurfaceInteractive() does and on the other hand to draw trajectories through the areas of interest in four easy steps.

    # open interactive application
spata_obj <- createTrajectories(object = spata_obj)

    2.1 Drawing

    Draw the trajectory interactively by clicking on the locations where you want the start and endpoints to be. If you click more than two times the trajectory is divided into sub-trajectory parts which will be displayed by subsequent plotting functions. Hence, it makes sense to stop everytime where you would expect a change as this will be highlighted by the transition from part to the subsequent one.

    Figure 2.1 Interactive trajectory drawing

    2.2 Highlighting

    If start- and end-points are set adjust the trajectory width to and click on ‘Highlight’.

    Figure 2.2 Highlight the trajectory

    2.3 Naming

    If you are satisfied with your trajectory enter a valid trajectory name and - if you want - a comment.

    2.4 Saving

    Click on ‘Save Trajectory’ and then on ‘Close application’ in order to return the updated spata-object.

    Trajectories are stored inside the object itself. Therefore createTrajectories() returns an updated version of the object that was specified as the function’s input now containing the additional trajectories.

    To obtain all trajectory names that have been drawn and saved in your spata-object use getTrajectoryNames(). Depending on the number of samples specified it returns a character vector or a list of such.

    # get trajectory names 
getTrajectoryNames(object = spata_obj)
    ## [1] "tumor-areas"

    3. Visualization

    3.1 Spatial course

    In order to visualize specific trajectories on the sample’s surface use of plotTrajectory().

    plotTrajectory(object = spata_obj, 
               trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
               color_by = "seurat_clusters",
               pt_clrp = "npg",
               pt_alpha = 0.25, # reduce alpha to highlight the trajectory's course
               display_image = FALSE) +
  legendTop()

plotTrajectory(object = spata_obj, 
               trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
               color_by = "nCount_Spatial",
               smooth = TRUE, 
               pt_alpha = 0.25, 
               display_image = FALSE) +
  legendTop()

    Figure 3.1 Surface related visualization of the trajectory

    3.2 Spatial trends and dynamics

    3.2.1 Trajectory trends via lineplots

    To display the trend of certain variables along a trajectory via lineplots use one of the following three functions:

    • plotTrajectoryFeatures()
    • plotTrajectoryGeneSets()
    • plotTrajectoryGenes()

    A call to one of those three functions will return a smoothed lineplot where the direction of the trajectory is mapped onto the x-axis and the values of the chosen aspects are mapped onto the y-axis. All functions follow the same concept and share the majority of their arguments. Still, they feature slight differences given the nature of their aspects to display.

    The following three arguments have to be set in order to specify the trajectory that is to be analyzed:

    • object
    • trajectory_name

    The way values are smoothed and displayed can be manipulated via:

    • smooth_method
    • smooth_span
    • smooth_se

    Features along trajectories

    Specify the features of interest via the argument features. Note that the function will compute the mean of all points on the axis orthogonal to the trajectory’s direction. As only numeric variables allow for such computation displaying the trend of categorical variables (e.g. cluster) is not possible via lineplots.

    plotTrajectoryFeatures(object = spata_obj,
                       trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
                       features = "nCount_Spatial", 
                       smooth_method = "loess", 
                       smooth_span = 0.2, 
                       smooth_se = TRUE)

    Figure 3.2 Visualization of ontinuous features along a trajectory

    In order to plot discrete features use plotTrajectoryFeaturesDiscrete().

    plotTrajectoryFeaturesDiscrete(object = spata_obj,
                               trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
                               discrete_feature = "seurat_clusters", 
                               clrp = "npg",
                               display_trajectory_parts = FALSE)

    Figure 3.3 Visualization of discrete features along a trajectory

    Genes and gene-sets along trajectories

    Specify the genes or gene-sets of interest by using the respective functions and arguments.

    # gene-set names
genes_of_interest <- c("CALM1", "VIM", "GFAP", "METRN")
  
# plot lineplot
plotTrajectoryGenes(object = spata_obj,
                    trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                    genes = genes_of_interest,
                    smooth_span = 0.2,
                    smooth_se = TRUE, 
                    display_facets = TRUE, # use facet_wrap() to split the plot in four parts
                    nrow = 2 # align the sub plots in two rows 
                    )

    Figure 3.4 Visualization of gene expression along a trajectory 

    plotTrajectoryGeneSets(
  object = spata_obj,
  trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
  gene_sets = "HM_HYPOXIA",
  display_trajectory_parts = FALSE) + # results in missing vertical lines 
  legendTop()

    4. Analyze & model trajectory trends

    Once a trajectory is drawn in the light of a biologic question or finding dynamics of additional variables can be easily visualized and investigated one by one. However, given that the average expression matrix contains tens of thousands of genes investigating all genes and gene-sets manually can quickly become a cumbersome task. By abstracting relevant biological dynamics into mathematical models the trajectory can be screened for variables (gene- and gene-set expression in particular) that correspond to these models.

    4.1 Predefined models

    To find variables that follow a certain trend along the trajectory of interest use assessTrajectoryTrends(). It fits the trajectory-trends of all specified variables to a variety of patterns/mathematical models (Figure 4.1) and assesses their fit by calculating the area under the curve of the residuals.

    all_genes <- getGenes(spata_obj)
all_gene_sets <- getGeneSets(spata_obj)

# obtain an assessed trajectory data.frame for all genes
atdf_genes <- assessTrajectoryTrends(object = spata_obj, 
                                     trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                                     variables = all_genes)

# obtain an assessed trajectory data.frame for all gene-sets
atdf_gene_sets <- assessTrajectoryTrends(object = spata_obj, 
                                         trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                                         variables = all_gene-sets)

# output example
atdf_genes
    ## # A tibble: 237,538 x 3
## # Groups:   variables [16,967]
##    variables pattern               auc
##    <chr>     <chr>               <dbl>
##  1 MT3       Gradient ascending  0.184
##  2 GFAP      Gradient descending 0.387
##  3 MT3       Linear ascending    0.387
##  4 PDCD6     Linear descending   0.404
##  5 GFAP      Linear descending   0.421
##  6 HSPA1A    Linear descending   0.423
##  7 MARCH6    Linear descending   0.445
##  8 MARCH6    Gradient descending 0.461
##  9 HOPX      Linear ascending    0.593
## 10 C3        Linear descending   0.619
## # ... with 237,528 more rows

    The resulting data.frame contains the evaluation of all fits for all provided variables. plotTrajectoryFit() visualizes the fitting results for a particular variable.

    # compare the trend of a variable to different models
plotTrajectoryFit(object = spata_obj,
                  trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                  variable = "GFAP", 
                  display_residuals = TRUE) + 
  legendTop()

    Figure 4.1. Visulization of the fitting results

    To get a summary of your trajectory assessment use examineTrajectoryAssessment() which displays the distribution of all areas under the curve measured. Use filterTrajectoryTrends() or a combination of dplyr::filter()and dplyr::pull() on your assessed trajectory data.frame in order to extract the variables following a specific trend to a certain quality-degree.

    # example 1: extract all variables that follow the linear descending trend while moving towards the hypoxic area (See Figure 2.1)
# with an auc-evaluation equal to or lower than 2
descending_genes <-
  filterTrajectoryTrends(atdf = atdf_genes,
                         limit = 2,
                         trends = "Gradient descending", 
                         variables_only = FALSE) # return a data.frame

descending_genes
    ## # A tibble: 29 x 3
## # Groups:   pattern [1]
##    variables pattern               auc
##    <chr>     <chr>               <dbl>
##  1 GFAP      Gradient descending 0.387
##  2 MARCH6    Gradient descending 0.461
##  3 HSPA1A    Gradient descending 0.735
##  4 PDCD6     Gradient descending 0.774
##  5 IL1B      Gradient descending 0.890
##  6 C3        Gradient descending 1.07 
##  7 EFEMP1    Gradient descending 1.28 
##  8 BCAN      Gradient descending 1.33 
##  9 HSPA1B    Gradient descending 1.38 
## 10 BEX1      Gradient descending 1.39 
## # ... with 19 more rows
    # example 2: extract variables that featured a peak along the trajectory 
# with auc-evaluation equal to or lower than 4
peaking_genes <-
  filterTrajectoryTrends(atdf = atdf_genes,
                         limit = 4,
                         trends = c("Early peak", "Late peak", "One peak"),
                         variables_only = TRUE) # return a vector of variables

head(peaking_genes)
    ## [1] "CKB"    "METRN"  "TMSB4X" "LPL"    "CALM1"  "ITGA3"

    4.2 Customized models

    The number of different trends that can be adopted by the expression of genes and gene-sets along a trajectory is potentially infinite. With the trends introduced in Figure 4.1 we integrated those that struck us a the most common ones to look for. If, however, you are interested in finding the variables that follow a highly specific pattern you can use the trajectory functions that are suffixed with ...Customized(). Before modeling spatial trajectories on your own you might want to have a deeper look into the theory and math underlying the concept. Click here to be guided to a more detailed explanation.

    4.2.1 Setting up a customized trajectory pattern

    Eventually a trajectory plot is composed of the expression averages of binned barcode-spots plotted against the trajectory’s direction. While the peaking trends might be a bit more complex to generate, the linear ascending trajectory pattern can be emulated quite easily as shown in the example below. What you need in any case to set up a pattern is the number of averages the trajectory of interest is composed of - we refer to that as the trajectory length.

    trajectory_length <- getTrajectoryLength(spata_obj, trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", binwidth = 5)

trajectory_length
    ## [1] 45

    Assuming we`d wanted to fit a linear ascending model we would need to generate a sequence - a numeric vector - of the same length as the trajectory.

    trajectory_direction <- 1:trajectory_length

linear_ascending <- scales::rescale(1:trajectory_length, to = c(0,1))

plotTrajectoryGenes(object = spata_obj, trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", genes = "GFAP") + 
  ggplot2::geom_line(mapping = ggplot2::aes(x = trajectory_direction, y = linear_ascending),
                     color = "blue",
                     size = 1)

    Figure 4.2 Visualization of a customized linear ascending model

    While the linear ascending trend isn’t particularly complex any other biologically relevant pattern can be abstracted into a pattern this way and the trend of certain variables (such as the expression of GFAP) along the trajectory can be fitted to that pattern. Apart from constructing customized patterns you can take the actual expression trends of certain variables and take them as the model to screen all the other variables for.

    traj_df <- getTrajectoryDf(object = spata_obj,
                           trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
                           variables = c("HM_HYPOXIA", # hypoxia gene set
                                         "METRN"), # METRN gene 
                           binwidth = 5, 
                           shift_wider = TRUE)

dplyr::select(traj_df, trajectory_part, trajectory_order, HM_HYPOXIA) 
    ## # A tibble: 45 x 3
##    trajectory_part trajectory_order HM_HYPOXIA
##    <chr>                      <int>      <dbl>
##  1 Part 1                         1     0.108 
##  2 Part 1                         2     0.0699
##  3 Part 1                         3     0.0995
##  4 Part 1                         4     0.122 
##  5 Part 1                         5     0.0916
##  6 Part 1                         6     0.148 
##  7 Part 1                         7     0.155 
##  8 Part 1                         8     0.0312
##  9 Part 1                         9     0.101 
## 10 Part 1                        10     0.102 
## # ... with 35 more rows

    The rows/observations of a trajectory data.frame obtained with getTrajectoryDf() refer to the bins that are aligned according to the trajectory’s direction. (The variable trajectory_order corresponds to the direction.)

    4.2.2 Fitting against customized models

    The variable HM_HYPOXIA of the data.frame traj_df naturally is of the same length as the trajectory itself. Assuming we’d want to screen genes along our defined trajectory to find those that behave similarly to the way HM_HYPOXIA is expressed we can take HM_HYPOXIA as our trend. The argument customized_trendstakes either a named list or a data.frame and automatically takes all numeric vectors/variables as models as long as they have the same length as the trajectory.

    atdf_cust <- assessTrajectoryTrendsCustomized(object = spata_obj,
                                           trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
                                           customized_trends = dplyr::select(traj_df, HM_HYPOXIA, METRN), 
                                           variables = all_genes
                                           )

atdf_cust
    ## # A tibble: 49,104 x 3
## # Groups:   variables [16,368]
##    variables pattern      auc
##    <chr>     <chr>      <dbl>
##  1 VEGFA     HM_HYPOXIA 0.466
##  2 GAPDH     HM_HYPOXIA 0.536
##  3 LDHA      HM_HYPOXIA 0.537
##  4 LGALS3    HM_HYPOXIA 0.679
##  5 SLC2A3    HM_HYPOXIA 0.745
##  6 MT1X      HM_HYPOXIA 0.756
##  7 IGFBP5    HM_HYPOXIA 0.779
##  8 ENO2      HM_HYPOXIA 0.847
##  9 IRS2      HM_HYPOXIA 0.864
## 10 ADM       HM_HYPOXIA 1.04 
## # ... with 49,094 more rows

    Now HM_HYPOXIA is the pattern and as we did with atdf which contained the results from the fitting against predefined models we can use filterTrajectoryTrends() to extract the variable names from atdf_cust to get those who resembled the expression dynamics of HM_HYPOXIA to a certain degree.

    similar_to_HM_HYPOXIA <- filterTrajectoryTrends(atdf_cust, limit = 0.8, trends = "HM_HYPOXIA")

# print names of similar genes
similar_to_HM_HYPOXIA
    ## [1] "VEGFA"  "GAPDH"  "LDHA"   "LGALS3" "SLC2A3" "MT1X"   "IGFBP5"
    # plot both in comparison 
plotTrajectoryGeneSets(object = spata_obj, 
                       trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                       gene_sets = c("HM_HYPOXIA"), 
                       display_facets = TRUE, 
                       clrp = "default")

plotTrajectoryGenes(object = spata_obj, 
                    trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                    genes = similar_to_HM_HYPOXIA[1:4], 
                    display_facets = TRUE)

    Figure 4.3 Comparison of the screening results against the HM_HYPOXIA-model

    The same can be done for gene sets similar to the expression of METRN.

    similar_to_METRN <- filterTrajectoryTrends(atdf_cust, limit = 2, trends = "METRN")

# print names of similar gene sets
similar_to_METRN
    ## [1] "NKAIN4" "CHKA"   "EDNRB"  "HIPK2"
    # plot both in comparison 
plotTrajectoryGenes(object = spata_obj, 
                    trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                    genes = c("METRN"), 
                    display_facets = TRUE, 
                    clrp = "default")

plotTrajectoryGenes(object = spata_obj, 
                    trajectory_name = "tumor-areas", 
                    genes = similar_to_METRN, 
                    display_facets = TRUE)

    Figure 4.4 Comparison of the screening results against the METRN-model

    5. Display trajectory trends with heatmaps

    Displaying the expression trends of too many variables in a lineplot gets unclear quite rapidly. In order to deal with several variables use plotTrajectoryHeatmap(). While the trajectory’s directory is still displayed from left to right the dynamic of the gene-sets’ expression values is now displayed by the gradual change of a row’s color instead of a line’s slope in a lineplot. The advantage of using heatmaps to display dynamic expression changes along trajectories becomes obvious when the number of variables to display rises.

    descending_genes_vec <- descending_genes$variables

hm_colors <- viridis::inferno(n = 100)

plotTrajectoryHeatmap(object = spata_obj, 
                      trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
                      variables = descending_genes_vec,
                      arrange_rows = "maxima",
                      colors = hm_colors,
                      show_rownames = TRUE,
                      split_columns = FALSE, 
                      smooth_span = 0.5)

    Figure 5.1 A heatmap displaying linear descending trends 

    plotTrajectoryHeatmap(object = spata_obj, 
                      trajectory_name = "tumor-areas",
                      variables = peaking_genes, 
                      arrange_rows = "maxima",
                      colors = hm_colors,
                      show_row_names = FALSE, 
                      split_columns = TRUE, # splits the heatmap to highlight the trajectory parts
                      smooth_span = 0.5)

    Figure 5.2 A heatmap displaying the gradual change of peaking genes
